title: RoboCop told woman to 'step out of the way' when she tried to summon police to break up fight
text:
A police robot which costs $70,000 to lease told a woman to 'step out of the way' after she tried to summon officers to break up a fight but couldn't do so because the emergency buttons are not connected.

The incident took place at Salt Lake Park in Huntington Park, just a few miles south of downtown Los Angeles, where the local police department is using one of the more than 70 'robotic security guards' created by Silicon Valley firm Knightscope.

Cogo Guebara, who witnessed the fight, ran over to HP RoboCop, the patrolling robot on wheels that runs a pre-programmed route through the park.

‘I was pushing the [emergency] button but it said, “step out of the way”,’ Guebara said.

‘It just kept ringing and ringing, and I kept pushing and pushing.’

HP RoboCop, the robotic patrolling officer, is seen above in Huntington Park, California

The machine recently failed to alert police when a witness who saw a fight break out in the park pressed the emergency button

Guebara thought that the robot, which is fitted with cameras, needed to get a visual of her face.

So she crouched down and posed for the camera, but that didn’t work either, according to NBC News.

A man who was with Guebara and her two children at the park then dialed 911. Police arrived 15 minutes.

But by that time, the fight had ended. One woman had to be wheeled out on a stretcher after suffering a cut on her head.

The robot continued on its way, rolling along the concrete path that slices through the park.

‘Please keep the park clean,’ the robot says when pausing periodically to tell park visitors.

Cosme Lozano, the chief of police in Huntington Park, said the alert button had not yet been connected to the police department.

Instead, any emergency calls are directed to Knightscope, the company that made the robot and leases it to police departments.

Cosme Lozano, the chief of police in Huntington Park, said there are still technical kinks to be ironed out as the department works to incorporate the new technology

‘That’s why we’re not advertising those features,’ he said.

‘It’s a new program for us and were still developing some protocols… to be able to fully adopt the program.’

Described as an 'autonomous data machine', HP RoboCop was unveiled in June.

Billed as a machine that ‘keeps a watchful eye on the public,’ it is equipped with 360-degree video cameras, which are then able to relay video footage to human police.

In addition to a two-way intercom and the ability to track cell phone use nearby, it is also said to be able to scan 1,200 license plates in a minute.

It beams this data to police headquarters in order to facilitate fast and safe responses from police officers.

They were created by Silicon Valley company Knightscope and are being used in select cities around the US at venues including malls, hospitals, stadiums and warehouses, according to the company's website.

More than 70 of these machines have been manufactured by the company so far.

Knightscope says the combination of self-driving technology, robotics, and artificial intelligence make them ‘crime-fighting autonomous data machines.’

But it appears it will take time before the machines are ready for duty.

Lozano said the robots are on ‘a trial basis for the city’ and that the police force is still working to incorporate the technology.

Huntington Park pays Knightscope between $60,000-$70,000 a year to lease the robot, according to Lozano.
description: A woman was taken to the hospital after suffering a cut to the head during an altercation in Huntington Park, just south of downtown Los Angeles. A witness tried to alert cops through HP RoboCop.
